post_text:
What a great first day so far! Although we were all probably a little nervous, things have gone even better than hoped.

Thank you for your patience and cooperation this morning. Even with temperature checks, almost every single student was in the building and ready to learn by 7:56. Awesome! Can we keep up that early arrival?! :)

Our teachers and students are amazing. We know there are some kinks to work out--especially for our distance learners (among other hitches, it sounds like there were Zoom failures nationwide as millions of students returned to school today)--but our plan is working! We have fewer students here on campus, they are learning safety protocols well, and I saw a lot of joy across campus. 💯

Distance learners, please hang in there. Our teachers are working to clarify everything for you. You also likely won't have as much of a load this week, as much of the learning is focused on classroom procedures.

Congratulations to former student Jason Gines, a Senior at a nearby high school. He was selected as a Delegate of Future Medical Leaders in Lowell, MA June 23-25, 2019. This Congress is and Honors only program for those who want to become physicians or go in to the medical research fields.

Jason's nomination letter was signed by Dr. Mario Capecchi, winner of the Nobel Prize in Medicine and the Science Director of the National Academy of Future Physicians and Medical Scientiste to represent Utah based on his academic achievement, leadership potential and determination to serve humanity in the field of medicine.

While there Jason heard from Nobel Laureates and top medical school deans, learned about cutting-edge advances and witnessed a live surgery. Jason will continue to be mentored and assisted in achieving his dream in the medical sciences and attributes his success to what he learned from attending Monticello Academy.

August is here, summer is almost over, and we're very excited for the new school year! Here are just three reasons you should be excited, too:

1. Our building renovation is in full swing! It's amazing what a fresh palette of colors can do. We can't wait for you to see it at Back to School Night on August 16th.

2. We have preliminary results from spring SAGE testing, and we successfully reversed a trend toward lower scores in the previous few years. In 3rd grade in particular, we outperformed every school--charter or district--in the area.

3. We have an amazing team of teachers to lead our Minutemen to new heights this year. In addition to the great teachers returning, we were able to recruit some amazing new talent.

Enjoy your last weeks of Summer Break!

This year, Monticello will be participating in the Snow Blitz program through Brighton Resort. This is an amazing opportunity for your child to learn a fun sport, get exercise, and make friends. All 6th-10th graders who are 11 or older are invited to participate.

This program provides 4 nights of skiing or snowboarding at Brighton and includes a lesson, lift ticket, rentals and transportation to and from the mountain. The price for four nights of skiing/snowboarding is $145 without rentals or $202 with rentals. The dates for this program are January 9th, 16th, 23rd, and 30th. (Tuesday evenings). The bus leaves right after school and returns to the school parking lot between 8:30 and 9:00.

If you are interested in this program, you can register here: http://www.slco.org/sports-office/ski--snowboard--snowshoe/Snow-Blitz-Session-1/

If you have any questions, please contact Emma Scanlon at emma.scanlon@monticelloacademy.net.

Please be aware that your 5th and/or 8th grade student(s) will be taking the Direct Writing Assessment (DWA) on Wednesday or Thursday this week (February 29th and March 1st).

The DWA is a summative assessment designed to evaluate each student's writing skills according to the state's 6-Traits writing rubric. This writing assessment is included in the 2012 core testing results commonly known as the CRTs (criterian-referenced tests). The results account for 5% of each student's English Language Arts (ELA) CRT score. The CRTs are also used on a federal level to determine Monticello Academy's Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP), as required under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 2002.

Please ensure that your student(s) get plenty of sleep and eat a good breakfast on the morning of the assessment. Doing so will help your student do his or her best on this very important state assessment.
